title: Peter Carington, 6th Baron Carrington
text:
Peter Alexander Rupert Carington, 6th Baron Carrington, Baron Carington of Upton, (6 June 1919 – 9July 2018) was a British <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a> politician and <a href="hereditary%20peer">hereditary peer</a> who served as <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Defence">defence secretary</a> from 1970 to 1974, <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Foreign%20and%20Commonwealth%20Affairs">foreign secretary</a> from 1979 to 1982, chairman of British <a href="General%20Electric%20Company">General Electric Company</a> from 1983 to 1984, and <a href="secretary%20general%20of%20NATO">secretary general of NATO</a> from 1984 to 1988. In the first government of <a href="Margaret%20Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a>, he played a major role in negotiating the <a href="Lancaster%20House%20Agreement">Lancaster House Agreement</a> that ended the racial conflict in <a href="Rhodesia">Rhodesia</a> and enabled the creation of <a href="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>.
Carrington had been Foreign Secretary in 1982 when <a href="1982%20invasion%20of%20the%20Falkland%20Islands">Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands</a>. He took full responsibility for the failure to foresee this and resigned. As <a href="NATO">NATO</a> secretary general, he helped prevent a war between Greece and Turkey during the <a href="1987%20Aegean%20crisis">1987 Aegean crisis</a>.
Following the <a href="House%20of%20Lords%20Act%201999">House of Lords Act 1999</a>, which removed the automatic right of hereditary peers to sit in the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>, Carrington was created a <a href="life%20peer">life peer</a> as Baron Carington of Upton.
Background and early life.
The surname "Carrington" (with two r's) was adopted by royal licence dated 1839 by his direct male ancestor <a href="Robert%20Carrington%2C%202nd%20Baron%20Carrington">Robert Carrington, 2nd Baron Carrington</a>, in lieu of Smith. The latter's father, <a href="Robert%20Smith%2C%201st%20Baron%20Carrington">Robert Smith</a>, MP for Nottingham, was created <a href="Baron%20Carrington">Baron Carrington</a> in 1796 (Peerage of Ireland) and 1797 (Peerage of Great Britain). The spelling of the surname was changed by royal licence to "Carington" (with one r) in 1880 by the 2nd Baron's sons, but the spelling of the title did not change.
Born in <a href="Chelsea%2C%20London">Chelsea</a> on 6 June 1919, Peter Alexander Rupert Carington was the only son of the <a href="Rupert%20Carington%2C%205th%20Baron%20Carrington">5th Baron Carrington</a> by his wife, <a href="The%20Honourable">the Hon.</a> Sybil Marion Colville, a daughter of <a href="Charles%20Colville%2C%202nd%20Viscount%20Colville%20of%20Culross">Charles Colville, 2nd Viscount Colville of Culross</a>. He was a great-nephew of the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> statesman <a href="Charles%20Wynn-Carington%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Lincolnshire">Charles Wynn-Carington, 1st Marquess of Lincolnshire</a>, and also of politician and courtier the Hon. <a href="William%20Carington">Sir William Carington</a>. Brought up at Millaton House in <a href="Bridestowe">Bridestowe</a>, <a href="Devon">Devon</a>, he was educated at two <a href="independent%20school">independent school</a>s: <a href="Sandroyd%20School">Sandroyd School</a> from 1928 to 1932, based at the time in the town of <a href="Cobham%2C%20Surrey">Cobham, Surrey</a> (now the site of <a href="Reed%27s%20School">Reed's School</a>), and <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>. Upon leaving Eton, his housemaster said of him, "For a really stupid boy, there are three possible professions: farming, soldiering and stockbroking".
Military service.
Having trained at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>, Carrington was commissioned into the <a href="Grenadier%20Guards">Grenadier Guards</a> as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> on 26 January 1939. He served with the regiment during the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a>, and played a key role as a tank commander during <a href="Operation%20Market%20Garden">Operation Market Garden</a> in the Netherlands in 1944. He was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> on 1 January 1941, and later rose to the rank of temporary <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> and acting <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a>. He was awarded the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a> (MC) on 1 March 1945 "in recognition of gallant and distinguished services in North West Europe". After the war, Carrington remained in the army until 1949.
Political career 1946–1982.
In 1938, Carrington succeeded <a href="Rupert%20Carington%2C%205th%20Baron%20Carrington">his father</a> as 6th Baron Carrington. Although he became eligible to take his seat in the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a> on his 21st birthday in 1940, he was on active service at the time, and did not do so until 9 October 1945. After leaving the Army, he became involved in politics and served in the Conservative governments of <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> and <a href="Anthony%20Eden">Anthony Eden</a> as <a href="Parliamentary%20Secretary">Parliamentary Secretary</a> to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Agriculture%2C%20Fisheries%20and%20Food%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Minister of Agriculture and Food</a> from November 1951 to October 1954. During the <a href="Crichel%20Down%20affair">Crichel Down affair</a>, which led to the resignation of Minister Thomas Dugdale, Carrington tendered his resignation, which was refused by the Prime Minister. Carrington then became Parliamentary Secretary to the <a href="Minister%20of%20Defence%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Minister of Defence</a> from October 1954 to October 1956. The latter year he was appointed <a href="List%20of%20High%20Commissioners%20from%20the%20United%20Kingdom%20to%20Australia">High Commissioner to Australia</a>, a post he held until October 1959. He was also appointed a <a href="Deputy%20Lieutenant">Deputy Lieutenant</a> of <a href="Buckinghamshire">Buckinghamshire</a> on 2 July 1951. He became a <a href="Privy%20Council%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Privy Counsellor</a> in 1959.
After his return to Britain he served under <a href="Harold%20Macmillan">Harold Macmillan</a> as <a href="First%20Lord%20of%20the%20Admiralty">First Lord of the Admiralty</a> until October 1963. These were the years of the Royal Navy's Indian summer, and Carrington completed his education in high level defence, largely playing a secondary role, with former CNS Lord Mountbatten, 'Burma' to even other Sea Lords, as the last Royal CDS achieving the restoration of the Royal Navy to equal status with the Army and RAF, and securing major ship orders with guided missile destroyers replacing, cruisers, and a large new nuclear submarine and Leander frigate building programme and interim retention of a large carrier programme. Carrington found Mountbatten impossibly vain and unrealistic in his pretensions, but thought that aircraft carriers and an amphibious task force allowing flexible intervention, and crucially easier withdrawal, than land forces, a better idea than the RAF 'island-hopping' alternative, believing that the Island bases would probably all have declared independence by 1975. The unrealistic nature of Mountbatten's large CVA01 carrier programme and Harold Macmillan's replacement as Prime Minister by <a href="Alec%20Douglas-Home">Alec Douglas-Home</a>, saw Carrington settle for <a href="Minister%20without%20portfolio%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Minister without Portfolio</a> and <a href="Leader%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Lords">Leader of the House of Lords</a> under Douglas-Home until October 1964, when the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a>s fell from power. From 1964 to 1970 he was <a href="opposition%20%28parliamentary%29">Leader of the Opposition</a> in the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>.
When the Conservatives returned to power in 1970 under <a href="Edward%20Heath">Edward Heath</a>, Carrington became <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Defence">Defence Secretary</a>, where he remained until 1974 when the Conservatives were voted out in favour of <a href="Harold%20Wilson">Harold Wilson</a>'s Labour. In a 1977 letter discussing the policy of torture of <a href="Irish%20republican">Irish republican</a> internees during <a href="Operation%20Demetrius">Operation Demetrius</a> in August 1971, the then Home Secretary <a href="Merlyn%20Rees">Merlyn Rees</a> attributed the origins of the policy in particular to Carrington: '"It is my view (confirmed by <a href="Brian%20Faulkner">Brian Faulkner</a> before his death [NI's prime minister at the time]) that the decision to use methods of torture in Northern Ireland in 1971/72 was taken by ministers – in particular Lord Carrington, then secretary of state for defence."
Carrington had become Shadow Defence Secretary in 1968 after <a href="Enoch%20Powell">Enoch Powell</a> was dismissed from the position following his controversial <a href="Rivers%20of%20Blood%20speech">Rivers of Blood speech</a> on immigration. He also served as <a href="Chairman%20of%20the%20Conservative%20Party">Chairman of the Conservative Party</a> from 1972 to 1974, and was briefly <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Energy">Secretary of State for Energy</a> from January to March 1974.
Carrington was again Leader of the Opposition in the House of Lords from 1974 to 1979. In 1979 he was made <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Foreign%20and%20Commonwealth%20Affairs">Foreign Secretary</a> and <a href="Minister%20for%20Overseas%20Development">Minister for Overseas Development</a> as part of the first <a href="Cabinet%20%28government%29">Cabinet</a> of <a href="Margaret%20Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a>. Thatcher spoke very highly of Carrington, stating that "Peter had great panache and the ability to identify immediately the main points in any argument; and he could express himself in pungent terms. We had disagreements, but there were never any hard feelings."
Carrington chaired the <a href="Lancaster%20House%20Agreement">Lancaster House conference</a> in 1979, attended by <a href="Ian%20Smith">Ian Smith</a>, <a href="Abel%20Muzorewa">Abel Muzorewa</a>, <a href="Robert%20Mugabe">Robert Mugabe</a>, <a href="Joshua%20Nkomo">Joshua Nkomo</a> and <a href="Josiah%20Tongogara">Josiah Tongogara</a>, which brought to an end <a href="Rhodesia">Rhodesia</a>'s <a href="Rhodesian%20Bush%20War">Bush War</a>. He later expressed his support for Mugabe over Smith.
Carrington was Foreign Secretary when Argentina <a href="Falklands%20War">invaded</a> the <a href="Falkland%20Islands">Falkland Islands</a> on 2 April 1982. He resigned from the position on 5 April, taking full responsibility for the complacency of the <a href="Foreign%20and%20Commonwealth%20Office">Foreign and Commonwealth Office</a> in its failure to foresee this development and for the misleading signals sent by the Foreign Office on British intentions for retaining control over the Falklands. In her autobiography, Margaret Thatcher was later to express her sorrow at his departure. She had asked him to stay but he left because he and the Foreign Office was distrusted and even hated by many back-bench Conservatives, and in turn he despised the party for its pettiness. Since his resignation, no other member of the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a> has held any of the four <a href="Great%20Offices%20of%20State">Great Offices of State</a>.
Later life and death.
Lord Carrington then served as <a href="Secretary%20General%20of%20NATO">Secretary General of NATO</a> from 1984 to 1988. He was also appointed Chancellor of the <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">Order of St Michael and St George</a> on 1 August 1984, serving until June 1994.
In 1991, he presided over diplomatic talks about the <a href="breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a> and attempted to pass a plan that would end the wars and result in each republic becoming an independent nation.
Apart from his political posts, he was the Chancellor of the <a href="University%20of%20Reading">University of Reading</a> and served as chairman of several companies, including <a href="Christie%27s">Christie's</a>, and as a director of many others, including <a href="Barclays%20Bank">Barclays Bank</a>, <a href="Cadbury%20Schweppes">Cadbury Schweppes</a> and "<a href="The%20Daily%20Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a>". He also chaired the <a href="Bilderberg%20conference">Bilderberg conference</a>s from 1990 to 1998, being succeeded in 1999 by <a href="%C3%89tienne%20Davignon">Étienne Davignon</a>. From 1983 to 2002, he was president of the <a href="Pilgrims%20Society">Pilgrims Society</a>, and from 1971 to 2018 the President of the <a href="Britain%E2%80%93Australia%20Society">Britain–Australia Society</a>. He was appointed <a href="Chancellor%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20Garter">Chancellor of the Order of the Garter</a> on 8 November 1994, a role from which he retired in October 2012.
After the <a href="House%20of%20Lords%20Act%201999">House of Lords Act 1999</a> removed the automatic right of hereditary peers to sit in the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>, Carrington, along with all former leaders of the House of Lords, was given a <a href="life%20peer">life peer</a>age on 17 November 1999 as Baron Carington of Upton, of Upton in the County of Nottinghamshire. He was the longest-serving member of the House of Lords, and following the retirement of <a href="Derek%20Barber%2C%20Baron%20Barber%20of%20Tewkesbury">Lord Barber of Tewkesbury</a> in 2016, had been the oldest. He was the second longest-serving member of the <a href="Privy%20Council%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Privy Council</a> after the <a href="Prince%20Philip%2C%20Duke%20of%20Edinburgh">Duke of Edinburgh</a>.
He died on 9 July 2018, aged 99, of natural causes in London; his son <a href="Rupert%20Carington%2C%207th%20Baron%20Carrington">Rupert</a> succeeded him as 7th Baron Carrington.
Family.
Lord Carrington married Iona McClean (19 March 1920 – 7 June 2009), daughter of Lt Col. Sir <a href="Francis%20McClean">Francis Kennedy McClean</a> and Aileen Wale, on 25 April 1942. They had three children: Alexandra de Bunsen (born 1943), Virginia Carington (born 1946; formerly married to <a href="Henry%20Cubitt%2C%204th%20Baron%20Ashcombe">Lord Ashcombe</a>), and <a href="Rupert%20Carington%2C%207th%20Baron%20Carrington">Rupert Carington, 7th Baron Carrington</a> (born 1948). Lord Carrington's wife, Lady Carrington, died on 7 June 2009, aged 89.
In popular culture.
Carrington was a guest on <a href="BBC%20Radio%204">BBC Radio 4</a>'s long-running programme "<a href="Desert%20Island%20Discs">Desert Island Discs</a>" in 1975 and on the same station's "<a href="A%20Good%20Read">A Good Read</a>" in 2004.
In February 1982 Carrington was portrayed by <a href="Rowan%20Atkinson">Rowan Atkinson</a> in a "<a href="Not%20the%20Nine%20O%27Clock%20News">Not the Nine O'Clock News</a>" parody of "<a href="Question%20Time%20%28TV%20series%29">Question Time</a>", pedantically discussing an imminent <a href="nuclear%20holocaust">nuclear holocaust</a>.
Carrington was portrayed by <a href="James%20Fox">James Fox</a> in the 2002 <a href="BBC">BBC</a> production of <a href="Ian%20Curteis">Ian Curteis</a>'s "<a href="The%20Falklands%20Play">The Falklands Play</a>".
He was also briefly portrayed by <a href="James%20Smith%20%28actor%29">James Smith</a> in the 2011 film "<a href="The%20Iron%20Lady%20%28film%29">The Iron Lady</a>", and by <a href="Jeff%20Rawle">Jeff Rawle</a> in the 2014 play "<a href="Handbagged">Handbagged</a>".
